Key Laboratory of Biomass Chemical Engineering of Ministry of Education, Department of Chemistry, Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310028 China Polylactic acid (PLA) is popularly used to replace some petroleum-based polymers due to its biodegradability. However, biodegradation of waste PLA requires specific bacteria, stringent conditions and long time. Catalytic recycling of waste PLA to valuable added products rather than composting is a sustainable green routine. In this work, catalytic alcoholysis of waste PLA to methyl lactate (MLA) was carried out over a SiO2 @UiO-66 derived solid acid (SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2). Characterizations indicated that SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 processed large surface area and homogenously dispersed acid sites, and it exhibited excellent performance for the alcoholysis of waste PLA under mild conditions. At 140 oC, the yield of MLA is 92.7% within 5 h, and SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 could be recycled at least five times without obvious loss of activity. The specific yield of MLA over SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 reached 2678 mg-MLA/g-cat/h, which was higher than that of H3PW12O40, Amberlyst-45, Hβ, HZSM-5 and α-ZrP. At the same time, SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 was also capable of the alcoholysis of waste PLA-based products. A possible pathway of PLA alcoholysis over SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 catalyst was proposed. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Polylactic acid Methyl lactate Alcoholysis Solid acid Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Plastic is everywhere around us, and it will accompany us for our whole lifelong. It is estimated that more than 9.2 billion tons of plastic have been manufactured all over the world, and plastic pollution has become a serious problem to environment and ecology both on land and in oceanic [1–4]. Meanwhile, landfilling and burning of waste plastic also bring severe pollution and additional CO2 emission [5–8]. Catalytic degradation and reuse of waste plastics have become a hot topic both in academic research and potential application [9–13]. Polylactic acid (PLA) is a biodegradable plastic, which is popularly used in the production of disposable dinnerware, plastic bags, and other products [14,15]. However, PLA biodegradation needs special bacteria in a environment of high temperature and humidity, and the natural degradation rate of waste PLA is low [16–18]. On the other hand, catalytic transformation of waste PLA to valuable added products is a sustainable routine in the viewpoints of environmental protection, controlling the emission of greenhouse gas, and reducing the over-reliance on fossil resources [19,20]. Hydrolysis and alcoholysis are the most popular processes for the chemical recovery of waste PLA [21–24]. Among them, alcoholysis of PLA can produce methyl lactate (MLA), which is an environmentally friendly solvent. And MLA may also be used to produce lactide, which can subsequently be transformed into PLA via ring-opening polymerization, resulting in a recycling economy [25,26]. In the past decade, several catalysts have been reported for the alcoholysis of PLA to MLA, such as ionic liquids [27,28], inorganic metal salts [29,30], and quaternary ammonium salts [31]. DBU-based ionic liquid can promote the depolymerization of PLA with a 91% MLA yield at 100 °C [28]. And FeCl3 is also capable of the alcoholysis of PLA at high reaction temperature (130 °C) and large catalyst dosage (10 mol%) with a 96% PLA conversion and 87.2% MLA yield in 4 h [30]. But these saline catalysts are poisonous and difficult to be separated. Solid acids are environmentally friendly, easy to separate and recycle, and non-corrosive to instruments [32,33], which could overcome the shortcomings of ionic liquids and salts catalysts. In this work, a novel SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 solid acid with high surface area and homogenously dispersed acid sites was synthesized via calcining and acidifying of SiO2 @UiO-66, and it was tested in alcoholysis of waste PLA into MLA ( Scheme 1). The structure and property of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 were characterized by various technologies. The performance and stability of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 for alcoholysis of PLA under different reaction conditions were evaluated in detail and compared with other solid acid catalysts. A possible reaction mechanism of PLA alcoholysis over SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 was proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Zirconium tetrachloride (98%), terephthalic acid (99%), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98%), methyl lactate (98%) and phosphotungstic acid (H3PW12O40·xH2O) were purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), acetic acid, sulphuric acid, ammonium hydroxide, methanol, anhydrous alcohol, chloroform and benzyl alcohol (99%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). Polylactic acid (PLA, particle size: 3 mm, Mw∼80000) was purchased from Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). Commercial resin (Amberlyst-45) was purchased from Dow Chemical Co., Ltd. Hβ (Silica-aluminum ratio of 25) and HZSM-5 (Silica-aluminum ratio of 25) were purchased from Huawei Ruike Chemical Co., Ltd (Beijing, China). α-ZrP was prepared according to reference [34]. Disposable PLA-based straws and disposable PLA-based cups were collected from Liaoning Jinliang Biotechnology (China). Disposable PLA-based knives were purchased from Isacco Industry & Trade (China). Deionized water was used in the experiments. All Chemicals were used as received without purification. 2.2 Catalysts preparation UiO-66 was synthesized according to reference [35], and the detailed preparation procedures were described in supplementary material section. And then, UiO-66 (0.5 g) was dispersed in TEOS (5 mL) and pretreated in ultrasound bath for 30 min. The mixture was transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and further stirred at 60 oC for 12 h. After that, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, and the precipitate was washed with methanol (5 mL). The collected sediment was hydrolyzed via a steam-assisted recrystallization method [36]. In a brief, a beaker containing a certain amount of sediment was placed into a Teflon-lined autoclave with 20 mL of deionized water (see Fig. S1) and was kept at 120 oC for 12 h to obtain SiO2 @UiO-66. SiO2 @UiO-66 was calcined in air atmosphere at 600 oC for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 oC/min to obtain ZrO2/SiO2. Finally, ZrO2/SiO2 (0.5 g) was impregnated in 1 mol/L sulfuric acid solution (10 mL) at room temperature for 6 h. The impregnated solid was collected via centrifugation and dried at 100 oC for 12 h. And the acidified solids were calcined in an air atmosphere at 500 oC for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 oC/min to obtain SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2. The real composition of the prepared catalyst was detected with inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, Thermo Elemental IRIS Intrepid). As references, pure UiO-66 derived SO2– 4/ZrO2 was also prepared in the same procedures as above. And traditional SO2– 4/ZrO2 (t-SO2– 4/ZrO2) was prepared according to the literature [37]. Those detailed processes were described in Supplementary material section. 2.3 Characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) data was collected at room temperature with a Rigaku SmartLab diffractometer with parafocusing Bragg-Brentano geometry using a Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) and operated at 40 kV and 180 mA. The scan range was from 5° to 80° (2θ) with a step of 0.02° and a scan rate of 10 °/min. Thermogravimetric differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DTG) results were obtained on a Netzsch STA 409 thermobalance from 25° to 800°C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in air (30 mL/min). N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded using an ASAP 2010 analyzer after pretreatment at 150 °C for 12 h in vacuum. The Brunner-Emmet-Teller surface area (S BET ) was calculated from the adsorption branch in the p/p 0 range of 0.005–0.1, and the pore size distribution was calculated using Nonlocal Density Functional Theory (NLDFT) method for micropores or Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method for mesopores. Fourier transform infrared spectrometry (FTIR) analysis was performed on a Nicolet Is10 FTIR spectrometer using a KBr tablet method. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were obtained on Hitachi SU8010 high-resolution cold field emission scanning electron microscope (Japan). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM 2100 F) was employed to observe the morphologies and energy spectrum analysis of the catalysts by using an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement was performed on a PerkinElmer PHI ESCA System, and the X-ray source was the Mg standard anode 146 (1253.6 eV) operated at 12 kV and 300 W. The acidity of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 was detected via an acid-base titration method. In a typical procedure, 0.1 g catalyst was dispersed in 30 mL KCl aqueous solution (1 M) and stirred for 24 h under the protection of purified N2. Then the acid sites in catalyst were neutralized by adding an aqueous solution of NaOH (0.05 M) by drops until the pH of the suspension reached 7, which was monitored by an online pH meter [38]. The type of acid sites in SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 was detected via pyridine-IR analysis, and these detailed procedures were described in supplementary material section. 2.4 Catalytic reactions In a typical run, PLA (0.5 g), SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 (0.05 g) and methanol (10 mL) were added into a stainless autoclave under stirring. Then, the autoclave was purged with N2 and pressed to 0.5 MPa. Subsequently, the autoclave was preheated to the required temperature and maintained for a required time under vigorously stirring (1000 rpm, in order to exclude the mass transport limitation). After reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature. The reaction mixture was centrifugated to remove solid catalyst and a certain amount of benzyl alcohol was added to reaction solution as an internal standard for quantitative calculation. The solution was analyzed with a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, 14B), fitted with a 30–m capillary column (DB‐WAX 52CB, USA), a flame ionization detector and an automatic sampler. The yield of MLA was calculated in the following equations: MLA yield (%) = (mol of MLA formed)/( mol of monomer equivalent in PLA) × 100 The recycling experiment was carried out in the same procedure and reaction conditions. In brief, the catalyst was separated via centrifugation (10000 rpm, 3 min) from the reaction system, washed with chloroform for five times, each time 5 mL, and dried at 100 oC in vacuum for overnight before next recycling. The molecular weight of remaining PLA solids in the reaction solution was determined using a Bruker Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time of Flight Mass Spectrometry (MALDI-TOF-MS) instrument. The remaining PLA solids were dissolved in CHCl3. The cationization agent sodium trifluoroacetate was dissolved in THF at a concentration of 1 mg/mL, and the matrix Dithranol was dissolved in CHCl3 at a concentration of 40 mg/mL. The solutions of PLA, salt and matrix were mixed, and then, several drops of the above mixture were placed on the sample table and dried at room temperature in a vacuum. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization XRD patterns of UiO-66 and SiO2 @UiO-66 were shown in Fig. S2. It was found that the primary diffraction peaks of UiO-66 and SiO2 @UiO-66 were similar to those reported in literature [39], which indicated that the structure of UiO-66 was preserved in SiO2 @UiO-66. The calculated cell parameters increased from 20.7925 (of UiO-66) to 20.8062 nm (of SiO2 @UiO-66) because of the deposition of SiO2. Fig. 1 and S3 compared the XRD patterns of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2, SO2– 4/ZrO2, t-SO2– 4/ZrO2 and their corresponding precursors, respectively. Several peaks at 2θ = 30.2, 35.0, 50.3 and 60.0° were detected in SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2, which could be attributed to the refection of (101), (002), (112) and (211) planes in tetragonal typed ZrO2 (JCPDS 00–068–0200) with small-sized particle (8.2 nm) [40]. On the other hand, the intensity of these peaks enhanced in SO2– 4/ZrO2 and t-SO2– 4/ZrO2, which might be caused by the formation of large-sized particles (12.9 nm and 41.2 nm). At the same time, additional peaks at 2θ = 28.2°, 31.4° and 40.9° that were identified as the diffractions of monoclinic ZrO2 (−111), (111) and (102) planes (JCPDS 01–083–0937) formed in SO2– 4/ZrO2 and t-SO2– 4/ZrO2 [41]. These results confirmed that introducing silica in UiO-66 could depress the formation of monoclinic ZrO2 and prevent the sintering of tetragonal typed ZrO2. Fig. 2 showed the TG-DTA-DTG curves of UiO-66 and SiO2 @UiO-66. There were three mass loss stages in both samples. The first mass loss stage (25–173 °C) was caused by volatilization of adsorbed solvent in the channel of UiO-66 and SiO2 @UiO-66. The second mass loss stage (173–421 oC) could be attributed to removal of bound water in UiO-66 structure and decomposition of Zr6O4(OH)4 into Zr6O6. The third mass loss stage (421–550 oC) was an obvious weight-loss stage, which might be caused by decomposition of organic ligand (terephthalic acid) [42]. After that, TG curves changed smoothly with rising temperature, indicating that UiO-66 and SiO2 @UiO-66 have been entirely transformed into ZrO2 and ZrO2/SiO2, respectively. According to above data, the calculated mass ratio of UiO-66 and SiO2 in SiO2 @UiO-66 was 85.4 wt%, 11.6 wt%, respectively. That is, the calculated content of SiO2 in ZrO2/SiO2 was 24.5 wt% (the calculation method was illustrated in Supplementary material section), and this content fitted well with that detected via ICP analysis (see Table S1). UiO-66 and SiO2 @UiO-66 had typical type I adsorption isotherms (Fig. S4a), indicating that both UiO-66 and SiO2 @UiO-66 were microporous materials. The pore diameter distributions of UiO-66 and SiO2 @UiO-66 were compared in Fig. S4b, and it was found that UiO-66 exhibited well-distributed double microporous pores with a size of 0.80 and 1.19 nm [35]. The diameters of these double pores in SiO2 @UiO-66 decreased slightly to 0.79 and 1.17 nm because of the deposition of SiO2. The specific surface area (S BET) and micropore volume of UiO-66 were 1140 m2/g and 0.43 cm3/g, while these values of SiO2 @UiO-66 decreased slightly to 868 m2/g and 0.37 cm3/g, respectively (see Table S2). These results indicated that TEOS was effectively hydrolyzed in the channel of UiO-66 to create SiO2 @UiO-66. The textural properties of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2, SO2– 4/ZrO2 and t-SO2– 4/ZrO2 were summarized in Table 1 and the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of these samples were shown in Fig. 3. The S BET of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 was 165 m2/g, and this value was several times higher than that of SiO2-free UiO-66 derived SO2– 4/ZrO2 and t-SO2– 4/ZrO2 prepared in the traditional method, which inferred that SiO2 in the channel of UiO-66 could enhance the surface area of final solid acid (SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2) even after calcination. The FTIR spectra of UiO-66, SiO2 @UiO-66 and SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 were presented in Fig. 4. The distinctive peaks in the range of 600–800 cm-1 and 1350–1700 cm-1 in UiO-66 fitted well with the previously described structure in literature [43]. And these peaks remained after the loading of SiO2 (in SiO2 @UiO-66). The distinctive signal at 1066 cm-1 were corresponded to stretching vibration of Si-O-Si [44]. The strong peaks at 1216 and 1150 cm-1 in SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 were ascribed to asymmetric stretching vibration of S-O bonds and might also be attributed to the adsorption of chelating double ligand between SO2– 4 and ZrO2. And the peak at 602 cm-1 was assigned to Zr-O bonds [45]. Typical SEM images and particle size distributions of UiO-66, SiO2 @UiO-66, ZrO2/SiO2 and SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 were shown in Fig. 5 and Fig. S5. The octahedral spatial structured UiO-66 was confirmed in Fig. 5a, and SiO2 @UiO-66 could keep the primary octahedral structure as UiO-66 (see Fig. 5b). The particle size of UiO-66 and SiO2 @UiO-66 were ranged in 798 ± 165 and 803 ± 184 nm (see Fig. S5a-b), respectively, indicating that SiO2 deposited mainly in the pore channels of UiO-66. After the calcination of organic ligand, the particle size of ZrO2/SiO2 decreased obviously to 556 ± 126 nm. But it was interesting to note that the octahedral shaped outline was retained due to the supportive action of SiO2 (acquired during hydrolysis). Meanwhile, the particle size of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 (542 ± 98 nm) was similar as that of ZrO2/SiO2 (see Fig. S5c-d), indicating that the impregnation of sulfuric acid did not destroy the morphology of ZrO2/SiO2. On the other hand, the particle size of SO2– 4/ZrO2 ranged in 311 ± 58 nm (see Fig. S6 a&c), which was smaller than the that of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2. t-SO2– 4/ZrO2 presented irregular particles with accumulation morphology (see Fig. S6b). TEM image and line-EDS analysis also revealed that S and Si elements dispersed homogenously in SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 ( Fig. 6). This highly dispersed SO2– 4 may improve the accessibility of superacid sites. XPS spectra of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 was shown in Fig. 7, and the obvious signals of Zr 3d, S 3p and Si 2p were detected in SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2. The high-resolution spectra of Zr 3d was deconvoluted into two primary components at 183.3 eV and 185.6 eV, which could be ascribed to Zr 3d 5/2 and Zr 3d 3/2 [46]. Two peaks with binding energies of 169.3 and 170.6 eV might be assigned to S6+ with low binding energy and S6+ with high binding energy in the S 2p spectra of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 [47]. The binding energy Si 2p appeared at 103.5 eV, which agreed well with the value published in literature [48]. The corresonding elemental content of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 (calculated from the ICP, TG and XPS results) were summarized in Table S1. The bulk content of S was similar to the surface content of S in SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 (0.9%). And the detected bulk content of SiO2 (24.9%) was larger than the surface content of SiO2 (20.1%) in SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2. Fig. 8 compared the pyridine-IR spectra of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2, t-SO2– 4/ZrO2 and SO2– 4/ZrO2. The characteristic band observed at 1450 cm-1 was ascribed to the coordinatively absorbed pyridine on Lewis acid sites, and the band at 1540 cm-1 was ascribed to the protonated pyridinium ion on Brönsted acid sites [34]. These results confirmed that both Lewis and Brönsted acid sites formed in these sulfated zirconia catalysts. And it was also found that SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 possessed more acid sites than that of SO2– 4/ZrO2 and t-SO2– 4/ZrO2. 3.2 Catalytic performance Fig. 9 presented the performance of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2, t-SO2– 4/ZrO2 and SO2– 4/ZrO2 for alcoholysis of PLA at 140 oC. It could be found that the mol yield of MLA on the base of mol of monomer equivalent in added PLA increased with prolonged reaction time over all catalysts in the order of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2＞t-SO2– 4/ZrO2 >SO2– 4/ZrO2 under the same conditions. Among them, the maximum mol yield of MLA raised to 92.7% within 5 h over SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2, whereas, only 58.6% and 45.7% mol yield of MLA were detected over t-SO2– 4/ZrO2 and SO2– 4/ZrO2. The highest activity of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 might be attributed to its biggest surface area (165 m2/g) and richest acidity (1.25 mmol/g), which could promote the dispersion of acid sites and enhance their activity for the alcoholysis of PLA. On the other hand, no reaction occurred without the help of catalyst as the detected yield of MLA was lower than 1%. The performance of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 and other traditional solid acid catalysts for the alcoholysis of PLA with methanol at 140 oC and 5 h were compared in Table 1. It was found that H3PW12O40 was active for this reaction, as the detected mol yield of MLA and its specific yield were 91.1% and 2632 mg-MLA/g-cat/h, respectively. Unfortunately, it was difficult to separate H3PW12O40 from the reaction mixture because it dissolved completely in methanol. The yields of MLA over Amberlyst-45, Hβ, HZSM-5 and α-ZrP were 13.2%, 29.0%, 9.0% and 1.1%, respectively, which were obviously lower than that of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 (92.7%). Above characterizations found that SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 has a higher surface area (165 m2/g) than that of H3PW12O40 (2 m2/g), Amberlyst-45 (24 m2/g) and α-ZrP (44 m2/g), making the acid sites of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 more accessible. The surface area of HZSM-5 (260 m2/g) and Hβ (484 m2/g) was found to be larger than that of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2, however, the pore diameter of these zeolites was small and their acidity was lower than SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 (1.25 mmol/g). These results further confirmed that large surface area, large pore diameter (4.2 nm) and homogeneously dispersed acid sites in SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 might be more efficient for the alcoholysis of PLA with methanol. And this catalyst and process can also make post-consumer PLA-based products, such as knives, cups and straws recycled efficiently. The mol yield of MLA reaches 84.1%, 85.4% and 87.6%, respectively, when these feedstocks were crushed and alcoholized at 140 oC for 5 h (see Fig. S7), the above-calculated mol yield of MLA from these real substrates assuming that they were pure PLA without additives. Fig. 10 compared the performance of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 for alcoholysis of PLA under different reaction temperatures. It was found that the mol yield of MLA increased obviously with rising temperature. The alcoholysis reaction completed within 2 h at 160 oC, with a 96.5% mol yield of MLA and it remained constant throughout the reaction period. And then, the complete alcoholysis of PLA prolonged to 4 h at 150 oC. After that, the mol yield of MLA decreased to 92.7% and 76.3%, respectively at 140 oC and 130 oC. These results indicated that reaction temperature was extremely important for the alcoholysis of PLA. Fig. 11 showed the performance of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 in alcoholysis of PLA with a varied amount of catalyst. It could be found that the mol yield of MLA enhanced obviously from 50.5% to 79.1% when the dosage of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 increased from 5 wt% to 7.5 wt% (of PLA), respectively. And then, the mol yield of MLA further climbed to 92.7% and 95.3% when 10 wt% and 20 wt% (of PLA) SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 was added in feed. These results indicated that SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 was active and capable of alcoholysis of PLA even with low concentration. The recycle usage of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 for alcoholysis of PLA at 140 oC and 3 h was shown in Fig. 12. It can be found that the mol yield of MLA decreased slightly from 65.2% to 60.3% in the five recycles. FTIR analyses result of spent SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 was compared with the fresh one in Fig. S8. The characteristic absorption peaks of spent SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 were similar to those of fresh material. These results indicated that SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 was stable and could be recycled in the alcoholysis of PLA. According to above data under varied reaction conditions, a potential reaction route of PLA alcoholysis over SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 catalyst was proposed in Fig. 13. At first, PLA was swollen or dissolved in methanol. The strong acid site in SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 would attack the carbonyl oxygen atom of PLA to increase the electropositivity of carbonyl carbon. And then, methanol could perform a nucleophilic assault on the activated carbonyl carbon of PLA. This process accelerated the breakdown of ester connections between the component units of PLA, yielding oligomers. The oligomers further reacted with methanol over SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 catalyst, and obtained MLA and new oligomers with lower molecular weights. The above steps repeated until the oligomers were completely transformed into MLA and SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 catalyst was regenerated [28,49]. Above suggestions were also confirmed by the MALDI-TOF-MS of fresh PLA and its remaining fragments at short depolymerization time (see Fig. S9). It was found that a large amount of ion peaks (m/e in the range of 1000–8000) formed in the residual solid after 1 h, and the amount of these polymer decreased with the prolonged reaction time. These results indicated that the depolymerization of PLA occurred at both chain ends and different locations along the polymer. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a novel SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 solid acid catalyst with a high surface area was prepared via calcination and acidification of SiO2-filled UiO-66. Characterization results indicated that SiO2 in the pore channel of UiO-66 could depress the formation of monoclinic ZrO2 and prevent the sintering of tetragonal typed ZrO2 in final SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 catalyst. The surface area of SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 was several times higher than that of SO2– 4/ZrO2 and t-SO2– 4/ZrO2, and acid sites dispersed homogenously in the framework of octahedral shaped SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2. This solid acid was extremely active and stable for alcoholysis of PLA with a 92.7% mol yield of MLA at 140 oC within 5 h. At the same time, SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 was also active for the alcoholysis of waste PLA-based materials. A possible reaction mechanism of PLA alcoholysis over SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 was proposed. These findings would pave the way for the production of valuable added products from waste PLA. coredata.dc:description: Polylactic acid (PLA) is popularly used to replace some petroleum-based polymers due to its biodegradability. However, biodegradation of waste PLA requires specific bacteria, stringent conditions and long time. Catalytic recycling of waste PLA to valuable added products rather than composting is a sustainable green routine. In this work, catalytic alcoholysis of waste PLA to methyl lactate (MLA) was carried out over a SiO2 @UiO-66 derived solid acid (SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2). Characterizations indicated that SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 processed large surface area and homogenously dispersed acid sites, and it exhibited excellent performance for the alcoholysis of waste PLA under mild conditions. At 140 oC, the yield of MLA is 92.7% within 5 h, and SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 could be recycled at least five times without obvious loss of activity. The specific yield of MLA over SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 reached 2678 mg-MLA/g-cat/h, which was higher than that of H3PW12O40, Amberlyst-45, Hβ, HZSM-5 and α-ZrP. At the same time, SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 was also capable of the alcoholysis of waste PLA-based products. A possible pathway of PLA alcoholysis over SO2– 4/ZrO2/SiO2 catalyst was proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Alcoholysis of waste PLA-based plastics to methyl lactate over sulfated ZrO2/SiO2 catalyst
